name: Jim Pepper
description:
'''Jim Gilbert Pepper II''' (June 18, 1941 â€“ February 10, 1992) was an American jazz saxophonist, composer and singer of [[Kaw people|Kaw]] and [[Muscogee Nation|Muscogee]] heritage.

He moved to [[New York City]] in 1964, where he came to prominence in the late 1960s as a member of [[The Free Spirits]], an early jazz-rock fusion group that also featured [[Larry Coryell]] and [[Bob Moses (musician)|Bob Moses]]. Pepper went on to have a lengthy career in jazz, recording almost a dozen albums as a bandleader and many more as featured soloist or sideman. Pepper and [[Joe Lovano]] played tenor sax alongside each other in an acclaimed band led by drummer [[Paul Motian]], recording three LPs in 1984, 1985 and 1987. Motian described Pepper's playing as "post-[[John Coltrane|Coltrane]]". [[Don Cherry (trumpeter)|Don Cherry]] was among those who encouraged Pepper to bring more of his Native culture into his music, and the two collaborated extensively. Pepper died of [[lymphoma]] aged 50.
